title: EM U4 p33 Review 3 Word formation

(VARY) of reasons. Someenjoy the challenge, others the feeling of
(EXCITE) they getfrom testing themselves. So although their actual
(MOTIVATE)may differ, people who participate in extreme sports probably share an inabilityto accept all the
(LIMIT) that most of us think of as normal.They experience a sense of
(SATISFY) with the routine ofeveryday life, and feel a need to push the boundaries of what is possible, tosee how far they can go. Is this similar to simply being
(COMPETE)? Possibly, but it may be more to do with having a dream. Of course
(PROFESSION) athletes who train for extreme events like thetriathlon or the marathon may hope for
(FINANCE) rewards, butprimarily it seems they like being different. They enjoy the feeling of beingset apart from other people by their
(ACHIEVE), which arethings most of us would fear to do. // Part 4: Key word transformation

title: U3 p33 UoE/Reading 'Hygge'
boby: Complete the text with one word in each gap.HYGGE: THE ART OF SIMPLE PLEASURESThe Danes are famous for being one of the world's happiest nations. One possiblereason
this could be the untranslatable concept of 'hygge'. Hyggehas already gained a lot of publicity outside Denmark. This is thanks to astream of recently published self-help books,
all urge us toembrace hygge in order to improve our sense of well-being and happiness.Writer, Helen Russell, who moved to Denmark several years
, is ahygge enthusiast. She has been fascinated by the idea ever
shearrived. Her book, The Year of Living Danishly: Uncovering The Secrets of theWorld's Happiest Country, makes it easy to understand
Helen and herfamily are still living
. Helen says 'hygge' can bedefined
'the absence of anything annoying or emotionallyoverwhelming'. It's all about being kind to yourself and celebrating the simplethings in life,
spending time with friends and family, or eatingice cream. So find your inner Dane – and do what makes you happy without feelingguilty about it.
